message_1:
A manufacturing company produces three products A, B, and C. The table below shows the production quantities and their respective costs in thousands of dollars.

| Product | Production Quantity | Production Cost |
|---------|---------------------|-----------------|
|   A     |         500         |        125      |
|   B     |         750         |        175      |
|   C     |         1000        |        250      |

Using principal component analysis, determine the linear combinations of production quantities that result in the maximum variance across the three products.
message_2:
To perform principal component analysis (PCA), we first need to create a data matrix with the given information. In this case, we have two variables: production quantity (Q) and production cost (C). The data matrix X will be:

X = |  500   125  |
    |  750   175  |
    | 1000   250  |

Next, we need to standardize the data by subtracting the mean and dividing by the standard deviation for each variable. 

Mean of Q: (500 + 750 + 1000) / 3 = 750
Mean of C: (125 + 175 + 250) / 3 = 183.33

Standard deviation of Q: sqrt(((500 - 750)^2 + (750 - 750)^2 + (1000 - 750)^2) / 3) = 250
Standard deviation of C: sqrt(((125 - 183.33)^2 + (175 - 183.33)^2 + (250 - 183.33)^2) / 3) ≈ 62.23

Now, we standardize the data matrix:

X_standardized = | (500 - 750) / 250    (125 - 183.33) / 62.23  |
                 | (750 - 750) / 250    (175 - 183.33) / 62.23  |
                 | (1000 - 750) / 250   (250 - 183.33) / 62.23  |

X_standardized = | -1    -0.937  |
                 |  0    -0.134  |
                 |  1     1.071  |

Now, we compute the covariance matrix of the standardized data:

Cov(X_standardized) = (1 / (3 - 1)) * X_standardized^T * X_standardized

Cov(X_standardized) = | 1.000   0.976 |
                      | 0.976   1.000 |

Next, we find the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of the covariance matrix. The eigenvectors represent the principal components, and the eigenvalues represent the amount of variance explained by each principal component.

Eigenvalues: λ1 = 1.976, λ2 = 0.024
Eigenvectors: v1 = | 0.707 |, v2 = | -0.707 |
                     | 0.707 |      |  0.707 |

The first principal component (v1) explains the most variance (λ1 = 1.976). So, the linear combination of production quantities that result in the maximum variance across the three products is given by the first principal component:

PC1 = 0.707 * Q_standardized + 0.707 * C_standardized

This linear combination will maximize the variance across the three products.
